column59: I bring following strengths to my role and the team: · My experience on the projects relevant to long term strategic planning of councils stormwater and floodplain management and floodplain resilience.· My technical skill in project management as a project manager.· My experience on– project formulation (based on Council’s corporate plan and community expectations),– procurement,– stakeholder consultations,– flood emergency management,– internal capacity building,– development assessment advice & flood impact assessment review,– customer services,– flood models, data, software and modelling computers maintenance;– maintaining liaison with other departments and external agencies related to community engagement, legal advice, finance, data collection/sharing, etc.;– Townsville Floodplain Management Strategy project (until May 2017);– CBD hydraulic model development for Waterfront Priority Development Area (PDA); and– City Wide Flood Constraints Project (2012-2014)· My specialization on– the flood modelling and water quality software (i.e. MIKE FLOOD, TUFLOW, XP-RAFTS, RORB, MUSIC) including pre- and post-processing tools (e.g. waterRIDE, ArcGIS);– the flood forecasting tool i.e. Flood Emergency Decision Support Software (FEDSS); and– flood mapping services (maintained in public website) including pre-processing. My expertise in working closely with the multi-disciplinary teams in a collaborative and open atmosphere to find solutions and deliver quality outcomes for Council, e.g.– Planning Team – in connection with planning scheme amendment for Lansdown Station Flood Maps and also for publishing new flood maps;– Development Assessment Team- supporting development with flood impact assessment and flood modelling data;– Disaster Management Team- planning intelligence support,– Townsville Water & Waste Team- Ross River Dam related projects;– Sustainability & Environmental Services Team- providing technical assistance in different environmental projects;– Future Cities- sharing models and data for their projects;– Marketing and Communications Team- for “have your say” related to draft flood map and development of messaging strategy for planning scheme amendment;– Stakeholder Engagement Team- with regard to planning scheme amendment;– Major Projects Team- technical assistance to different projects;– Procurement Team- for tendering;– Finance;– Legal Services- with regard to sharing data, confidentiality agreement etc.; and others. · My capacity to actively engaged with the community, the key stakeholders and the government agencies and maintaining liaison with external agencies: e.g.– Queensland Reconstruction Authority (QRA)- providing updates on the QRA funded projects;– BoM- with regard to advice and data collection;– Department of Main Roads (DTMR)- with regard to their projects, data collection and data sharing;– Queensland Rails (QR)- data collection and sharing;– Townsville Port- data and model sharing (both way);– Development Industries – sharing data. Following activities may be considered as my strength to my role: · I always research latest technologies and relevant industry trends and adopt new technology when necessary;· I have been keeping TownsvilleMAPS updated with the latest the flood maps and information (i.e. updating flood parameter maps and flood alerts) with the help of Geospatial Service and understand the feedback on planning scheme;· Exercise responsibility within a council structure including Workplace Health and Safety, Environmental Protection, Anti-discrimination, and privacy obligation; and· Customer Service- Providing timely and quality customer service relating to flooding queries in accordance with the Service Excellence Charter.
column60: My professional goals are to excel in my current role by continuing professional development, to provide high quality service to the community, and to contribute in my field to enhance the liveability and to support investment to grow Townsville. We have developed the new flood models and flood hazard mapping for Townsville based on latest approach and methodology and data under Townsville Recalibrated Flood Modelling and Mapping Project. In the next 5 years we will be utilising these flood models and flood hazard mapping data to inform the Planning Scheme Amendment via floodplain risk assessment and to complete the projects under Townsville Floodplain Resilience Program (TFRP). The projects under the TFRP are mentioned below: · Total flood warning system, Phase II (Recovery and Resilience Grant Project): Procurement of a fit-for-purpose total flood warning system for flood forecasting and disaster management. · Flood Emergency Management Plans (Recovery and Resilience Grant Project): Development of flood emergency management plans (FEMPs) based on the updated flood model results and the lessons learnt from 2019 flood event & thereafter. · Ross River Dam Gate optimization (Recovery and Resilience Grant Project): Investigation into the opportunities for improved flood resilience outcomes on the Ross River associated with changes to the operation of the Ross River Dam gates. · Flood Classification Update: Updating of flood classifications for all stream gauges based on the newly developed flood model results. · Flood Information Portal (Queensland Resilience and Risk Reduction Funded Project): One stop shop TCC web portal, features & functions for Townsville flood matters effective for raising public awareness of flood risk and as a flood information reference incorporating newly developed flood-study results.  · Flood Resilient Building Guideline:  Floodplain risk is largely borne by existing residents within the floodplain. Improving the resilience of residential buildings will be achieved through:– Reviewing the range of literature available for flood resilient buildings, along with the local building typologies and issues;– Developing a locally specific flood resilient buildings guideline for the building industry and general public;– Engaging with appropriate stakeholders on the guidance materials;– Consideration of ongoing flood resilient building investment programs or property buy-back programs within the flood resilience and mitigation investment plan.  · Business Continuity for Flooding:  In the wake of the 2019 flood, small business has been disproportionally affected for a range of reasons. Improvements in the resilience of business will be pursued through:– A review of the business issues experienced through the 2019 flood event and recovery in collaboration with the economic recovery group, chamber of commerce, and insurance sector.– Developing a locally specific guideline for small business, business continuity planning for flooding;– Engaging with appropriate stakeholders on the guidance materials– Consideration of ongoing flood resilient business investment programs within the flood resilience and mitigation investment plan  · Flood resilience and mitigation investment plan: The identification of future investment priorities for floodplain resilience will be developed in accordance with the Queensland Disaster Resilience and Mitigation Framework (QRA 2019) as follows:· Issue Identification (part of this work in progress under “Flood Risk Based Land Use Planning- Grant Funded Project”):o Collecting information in the wake of 2019 flood;o Base-line flood modelling;o flood hazard and risk analysis;o Identification and evaluation of a range of options;o Review of the shocks and stressors for the community· Alignment to broader government policy:o Stakeholder engagement;o Policy review;o Identification of project objectives to align with policy requirements;· Cost Benefit Analysis:o Evaluation of effectiveness (flood modelling, appropriate consultation, literature reviews, avoided costs)o Review of scalability particularly with respect to climate change adaptation;o Whole of life costs and return on investment assessment;o Determination of qualitative and intangible benefits;· Evidence based:o Financial, social and physical impacts from flooding 2019 flood;o Latest research on damages and resilience/mitigation measures;o Environmental planning requirements;o Flood modelling; ando Risk assessment.· Community benefits realisation;o Identification of improved infrastructure resilience;o Identification of community and social benefits;o Targeting maintenance and restoration natural floodplain functions where appropriate;o Outlining opportunities for community education and capacity building.· Collaboration:o Working with stakeholder departments in the identification of issues and options;o Using appropriate methods to incorporate community input;o Ensuring key partner agencies are involved appropriately in the identification of issues and options;o Identifying opportunities for synergies with other resilience activities· Innovation:o Identifying opportunities for innovation particularly where they result in reductions in cost, timing or risk. Any flood mitigation infrastructure considered for the flood resilience and mitigation investment plan, will be supported through technical analysis of flooding on a catchment by catchment basis involving:· Phase 1 – Base-line flood modelling and historical flooding review;· Phase 2 – Flood Hazard and Risk Analysis;· Phase 3 – Options Development and Analysis; An Overall Flood Resilience and Mitigation Investment Plan will be developed for Townsville on the basis of feasible investment strategies for improving flood resilience and flood mitigation. The investment plan will identify ongoing programs, in addition to asset upgrades and potential new assets worth investment for improving flood resilience and flood mitigation.

column16: I think one of my greatest achievements at TCC is my experience working in all difference areas of finance. I have completed multiple secondments in the financial reporting & asset accounting team.  In my financial accounting role, I completed a review of council's fuel tax credit calculations, which found council was eligible to retrospectively claim an additional $900K of fuel tax credits. I also updated our methodology and calculations going forward to ensure this fuel was captured in the monthly claim.  Another area I did well in my current role was reviewing and interpreting the new accounting standards for revenue recognition. Transiting to these new standards was complex and involved lots of accounting research/interpretation/liaising with the LG Department. I completed numerous technical accounting papers to support my recommendation, and this was accepted by external audit which set the standard across Council. I also managed the setup of various GL accounts to accurately recognise revenue and ensure transactions were recorded in our accounting system correctly.
column17: My ability to work autonomously in completing the tasks required within my role and finding areas of improvement or ways to do things more efficiently.  I have also developed good relationships with my colleagues and communication within our teams is really good and effective. I provide a good service and will always help out where I can. I love being able to work through issues and find a solution which is another one of my strengths.

column16: I successfully led and PM'd the rollout of Okta MFA across the whole organisation. I really put my heart and soul into getting this project over the line including producing training videos and personally presenting information sessions and training from crack of dawn Toolbox sessions to Council Meetings with the Mayor and Councillors. As a result, we had over 1800 enrolments across the whole of the business, at the time of Office365 go-live. I stepped up as the unofficial Champion of Bookable when there was no Sponsor or support and also was instrumental in rolling this product out to multiple sections of Council.I have worked hard to become a more confident and stronger communicator:§ I have taken every opportunity to facilitate ILMs to the point of running three separate sessions in the one week. I have run over 60 ILM workshops across the whole of Council on many varied topics and each one was a mini roadmap of what investments they want to make and where the business wants to get to.§ I have represented ITS in the Corporate Induction. I have garnered feedback from L&D (Paul) which has been highly positive.§ I have enjoyed leading the ITS Christmas Committee – organising Christmas party functions and decorating the office in my own time.I have enjoyed mentoring new BAs who have joined ITS, as the BA with the longest tenure.I have pumped out multiple business cases over a short period of time during the budget process. I quickly had to grasp what stakeholders wanted, understood the problems they were trying to solve (if any) and from this, develop a detailed business case.
column17: I am:Highly creative – if I apply myself to a problem or task, I can come up with innovative ideas. I find people come to me for help with ideas and then follow my direction e.g., HCD study, how to facilitate workshops, problem solve and even decorating the office.Confident presenter – I really enjoy presenting and I take on as many opportunities as possible e.g., I put my hand up to represent ITS in the Corporate Induction. This was meant to be run by the leadership team with support from BPs, but I volunteered to facilitate. That is not to say that I am perfect! I am still a work in progress with much to learn in this space and I am really enjoying the journey!Empathetic person – I genuinely care about people and try to see things from their point of view and consider their feelings. This helps to build strong relationships with stakeholders – I don’t have to fake it. I think that’s why I was nominated by my peers as Most Inspiring and Culture Champion/Morale Booster in last two year’s Business Services awards.High EQ – this is something I have worked hard on and helps to take the heat out of the situation and distance myself from disagreeable people and hostile situations.Life-long learner - I am constantly learning through reading, listening to Podcasts and undertaking any training I can get my hands on! If I get a whiff of a learning opportunity at work, I am the first in line before anyone else even knows there is an opportunity!Always up for a challenge – I have travelled around the world with only a backpack, hiked to Everest Base Base, Kilimanjaro, Macchu Pichu to name but a few, I have run a marathon, survived a law degree, earned my skydiving license and I am still smiling and ready to say yes to the next challenge or opportunity.Happy to put my hand up for anything – especially if it helps someone else and reduced their load or puts a smile on their face - Mental First Aider, First Aider for ITS, Christmas decorations, ITS Christmas Party Committee.Energetic - I can whip myself and others up into a frenzy of energy and excitement - I find it easy to motivate myself when I understand the "why" and then I use this to also motivate others.The written word - I can write to motivate, move, inform, generate energy and make people laugh!Resilient - I have had some work and persona; challenges in my life that has increased my pain threshold and has put me in good stead to soldier on through stressful periods and also be able to offer support to others in difficult times.Loyalty - I have worked at Council for nearly ten years and I have a sincere wish to be of service and contribute to supporting my community.

column16: November 22: ServiceNow major upgrade in an unexpectedly short time. Delivered the BAU Project Management aspects of the upgrade and with the assistance of David House we delivered the upgrade in 2 weeks instead of 4. Meaning that we were able to provide the environment back to our internal and external developers earlier than expected.October 22: LMS version upgrade and restoration to OOB. Requiring extensive troubleshooting and testing. Unfortunately, the upgrade was not as smooth as expected, even with vendor assistance, however workarounds were identified and implemented.June 22: Okta setup for ServiceNow. A last-minute integration into the Okta project to move from Azure SSO to Okta SSO. All occurring within one month.CXone management: Ongoing improvement and identification of BCP improvement points and recently the identification of improvements to the CXone IVR scripts that will be required soon. Assisting ITS Business Partners with information gathering and system breakdowns.Change Manager role: With the departure of our ITS Service Desk Coordinator, who occupies the role of Change Manager, I volunteered to retain the role until its new occupant is found. During my time in the role, I have made improvements to Change Management processing to allow smoother processing of changes for staff, both within the product and with how the change process is handled. Continued consultation with CAB attendees and Management to allow feedback on process and handling. I have also placed myself into the fold of some major incident proceedings as to get a step ahead on making sure process is followed as simply as possible. And finally, now that the ITS Service Desk Coordinator position has been filled, I have begun the hand over to them.SNOW: Configuration of the SNOW integration to allow syncing between SNOW and ServiceNow. An element of the CMDB that may be used in the future.Web Feed Back mailbox ingestion into ServiceNow: A critical piece of the workflow for the Digital Design & Operations team. Allowing their emails to be directly taken from their mailbox and placed into records in ServiceNow for them to action.Maintained an excellent level of reliability with work performance and quality. Based on the level of responsibility placed upon me to complete tasks in a self-directed manner. While also being aware that there is room for improvement in all aspects of my work.
column17: I bring an extensive experience of each area of how ITS functions. I have worked with peers and colleagues to:- Enable customers to self-service- Enable resiliency in customer workflows- Create documentation for new and existing systems as they change or require review- Solve complex and role-segregated system issuesI bring my rigid stance on safety for all staff and members of the public.

column18: I would eventually like to be recognised and acknowledged within Council as a subject matter expert within Council; someone who is respected in their position title and renumerated accordingly.   A CD Practitioner that works across all areas of Council to impart relevant CD knowledge about new concerns, achievements and opportunity for inclusive partnerships to make our city more liveable. What I am most excited about at work? I would not use the word “excited” when it comes to working. I would rather use the word motivation as I value honesty, the integrity of my practice and work ethic more than something that can only last a few minutes or days.”I am most motivated about collaborating and working towards something big— a common goal. Every day at work is an opportunity I have to contribute to the growth of the community and council together. And this is what makes my day. It brings satisfaction and inner tranquillity knowing that I have done my best to improve something or create something greatThe most motivating thing to me about my CD job is that it keeps me busy. I love being busy, especially when I am doing something I like to do.I want a healthy work environment to work in, so embody positivity and safety to try to ensure everyday is as good as can be.The evolution of community and other council staff is what excites me the most at work. In my opinion, every day at work is another chance to shine, another opportunity to build something that will benefit my professional life, my community and council in the future. That is the reason why I come to work.I try to constantly engage in new things at work. I try to always give it everything I’ve got and if it’s not enough, at least I can’t say I didn’t try.  When I am at work, I know that I can make someone’s day easier by doing my job. I can create something that people enjoy and that will help the community connect with other community, the environment and in-turn provide improved wellbeing.Community Development is a linear area of work so my desire to improve my skills through learning everyday continually helps me have a great career. It is thinking of the long term that helps me to go to work every day.“Knowing that I am making a difference and that I can help people is what motivates me to go to work every day.

column16: In my current role as Senior Urban Design Officer in the Land Use and Urban Design Team, I have experience with acting as the Land Use and Urban Design Team Coordinator and previously as the coordinator for the Heritage and Urban Planning Unit. My commitment to the team was to encourage an enjoyable working environment, where we could grow our knowledge base from sharing, learning and self-guiding, or giving it a go, to develop additional skills and get satisfaction from our roles at Townsville City Council. Most of our projects are the results of collaboration across departments.Several projects have been successfully delivered over the years including the Ross Creek Waterfront Promenade Masterplaning and delivery of several sections of the promenade. Masterplan and delivery of the CBD Street Tree program. North Queensland Stadium precinct masterplan and delivery. Several strategic documents that will help guide the future of the city for years to come have been developed including the The Waterfront PDA Design Guide, where strategies for lighting, wayfinding, public art and urban design have helped deliver improved outcomes for the waterfront PDA.Over the last 8 years I have developed a good relationship with the Development Assessment Team that has allowed better collaboration while assessing development applications to improve Urban Design, Character Residential and heritage outcomes.

column18: My professional goals in the next 5 years are to maintain meaningful employment, working as available to suit my personal requirements of parenting 2 young children (one pre-school aged), and to contribute financially to meet my family and lifestyle needs.  Outside of my commitment to my family, I would be interested to pursue a role that is permanent part-time and offers the usual leave and superannuation entitlements enjoyed by other permanent staff. When my youngest child reaches school age I will be ready to return to work in a full-time capacity (at least 4 years away).  With my current family and lifestyle, I am excited to come to work because I don't have 2 children to look after.  The difference of working with adult co-workers and not having to "parent" is very refreshing and recharges my need to feel like a grown up.  Working helps to define my sense of being something other than a wife and mum.  As proud as I am of my children and as much as I enjoy my role in the home, it is very different to the duties I perform in the VSS role. I would be more excited to come to work if I didn't have to wear these incredibly heavy and cumbersome steel cap boots.  I would prefer a less physical role, and would be excited to come to work knowing that I wasn't going to get excessively sweaty.  I would be very excited to be able to wear more flattering clothes.

column18: My Professional goal is to further build my career in community education and engagement across water/the environment. column16: I believe I have achieved a lot during my time with Council. I have achieved career progression, having started as a Gallery Assistant, then Education and Programs Assistant, then Education and Programs Officer, to my current role as Senior Education and Programs Officer.  I have ‘learned experience’, working my way up in terms of career path means I have entered the senior role with experience in each of the roles I manage which I think is invaluable.  I think another thing I would say what I have done well is build, develop and maintain really good working relationships within my team and the greater Gallery team, something that I believe is absolutely essential in my role. It means I have really good working relationships and it also means delivering Council goals are easier as we work well together to deliver them as a team.
column17: I think my strengths include:Being personable (interpersonal skills): building relationships with my team so that we can work well to deliver outcomes collaboratively. I believe that leading a team also involves staying open and listening to my team members and offering encouragement.Organisational skills: I am highly organised and utilise tools such as One Note, Calendars, Emails, Excel spread sheets and regular meetings to manage many projects and deadlines.Creativity: I think creativity is a big one for the Education and Programs team, whether it be literal creativity in the programs we come up with, or even creative problem solving.Communication: I think I am an effective and clear communicator with my team, clearly communicating tasks and goals so that we can meet said goals. I also listen to others and take on feedback. Communication is always an area to learn in as well and I jump at any opportunity to further my communication skills.Safety First: I have learnt a lot working at Council about safety in the workplace and always put safety first. Positive safety approach has become second nature and part of every process in the Gallery.Sound knowledge of the Galleries’ role in the Community and its contribution to a vibrant and inclusive arts scene in the City.

column16: LeadershipAs well as providing direction, inspiration, and guidance, I have demonstrated courage, passion, confidence, commitment, and ambition. We are committed to achieving corporate plan goals as I cultivate the strengths and talents of our communications and marketing team. When I trust my team to complete what is assigned with excellence, positive morale, culture, and mutual respect are created.· Completed the Alliance Emerging Leaders Course (18 months).· Expanded team – Communications and Marketing, Social Media, Design, Content Production and Internal Communications.Mentored two JCU interns helping them both learn and progress through their own campaigns.· Community leader (Queensland Football Female coach of the year 21)· Panel member for Alliance Learning – Foundations for Leadership course presentationsBest practiceIn terms of distribution, content and presentation of collateral, we are continuously revising our communications and marketing strategies, which offers ways to differentiate Council communications from those of other leading organizations, cut through the “noise” in the marketplace, and promote Council more effectively. Trying to connect with audiences creatively is always a priority for the team.· Expanded team to operate in an environment like an agency. Social media, four designers, internal communications.· Adopting best practice through accessibility, developing the right concept, choosing the right channel, creating the right content, taking the initiative.· Overseeing a team of 17. Facilitating over 1,000 campaigns to our community a year.Communications and marketing processThe implementation of effective processes has improved the efficiency, effectiveness and brand control of communication and marketing support services. As a result, the team is better positioned to achieve industry-leading practice standards and instil quality in communication messages, assets, and services.· Internal Marketing Brief· Implementation of communication plan templates· Monday.com (now used by four other departments)Project managementIn the campaigns that I lead, I integrate a defined framework through project management. In this way, the narrative and vision can be coordinated, communicated, and carried out across multiple teams and campaigns simultaneously. I ensure that the project progresses through defined phases and reaches milestones in the required timeframes. There are manageable pieces, the big picture is considered, and each team member knows the expected results.· Brand refresh· Sponsorship – event activations ie: Rugby, Matildas and Origin· Draft internal communications strategy* Delivery and hands on of multiple major campaigns

column16: As I am only begining my secondment role in the System Engineering Team, I will speak about my nominal role in the Technical Support Officers Team. I have consistenly ensured that all task/jobs assigned to me are completed to a high standard and in a timely manner wherever possible. I have been a key resource/guide to the other members of the team in areas that I am more proficient in (Networking). I also provided leadership to the team for a month in an acting capacity, a role I enjoyed and thrived in. I believe that even when I was not acting as the team lead, I displayed leadership by taking the lead in P1/P2  and other escalated jobs. I also achieved a good rapport with Property Services whom we support on a regular basis (due to the nature of their operations interonking with IT resources) and ensured their requests were fulfilled in a timely manner I also made an effort to 'beyond the surface' with fellow team members to find out how they were actually doing as part of checking on their general well-being.

column20: Progression at TCC is twofold: within our discipline; and within TCC systems and tools. I feel I am still weighed down by those aspects of this role and general TCC business that I do not understand well, such as financial systems and tools. Training on these matters has been nought to minimal and I have mostly taught myself. I still do not ever see L&D options that focus on how local government works, how we can utilise tools, how we can be more efficient within the systems that we use. The idea that we sit in a matrix organisation, that someone else is the expert and we don’t need to know how things work seems counterproductive to learning and development.Specifically, I'd be interested in doing a Corporate Services specialisation of a diploma of local government: https://training.gov.au/Training/Details/LGA50120 I have little interest in doing sporadic non-accredited training unless it is for TCC ways of working.

If there are opportunities to enhance skills and broaden capabilities, I would welcome the opportunities, but really only so far as they would add value to my current position. For example:· In 2009, I – along with a small group of colleagues – were enrolled in an LGAQ course: Diploma of Local Government – Planning. This gave me great insight into work done primarily by my colleagues in Development Assessment.· in 2012 and 2013, my then-supervisor and I attended a ‘summer school’ heritage program in Canberra (now no longer offered), which was nationally recognised for its excellence, and it gave me skills that I have been able to put to use ever since.· I attended a weeklong Placemaking conference in 2015, which resulted in a great many papers and presentations, which I still refer to often and forward to colleagues in relation to Placemaking projects in Townsville· In 2016 I completed a three month secondment in the Local History section of CityLibraries, which gave me a different perspective on what resources are available and more direct interaction with members of the public· I have attended several statewide ‘Heritage Officer Conferences’, and find these to be useful to maintain connections with counterparts at other councils, and state government heritage staff.

I have served the community with high commitment to the ideals of providing a safe environment for members of the public to find enjoyment in their everyday and leisure activities by providing a strong deterrent to ineffective animal management practices .I have displayed passion in the promotion and observation of good management practices which has positive spin offs for both animal welfare and community safety.In doing this, I value and respect the dignity of both animals and members of the public I encounter.One of my better achievements has been the honest and consistent approach to patrol regimen. An ability to work in a steady, persistent way with an organized game plan is needed to be effective.

column16: As a Sustainability Systems Officer for TCC, I specialise in Education for sustainability and my key capabilities include writing and developing sustainability and environment educational programs. I create and deliver community-based projects that encourage citizen science. The project’s aim is to intrinsically motivate Townsville students andteachers to participate critically and act creatively throughout our programs to determine more sustainable ways of living. These programs enhance Townsville’s local teachers’ capacity to deliver sustainability units that specifically align with curriculum and the Townsville region. The programs I have written use complex, real-world sustainability issues as the subject matter. As part of my role, I encourage Townsville students to develop future-focused, critical thinking, and problem-solving skills to learn by doing and creating. To successfully deliver this project I knew that I had to extend myself professionally and consult with various colleagues, contractors, and community stakeholders. Develop environmental and sustainability youth skills through communication, involvement, and capacity building. In 2021, TCC Environmental Sustainability Services team hosted three 4th year Bachelor of Education Students. I was the mentor for the three students’, and provided them with information, task lists, organised workshops for them to attend with subject matter experts, provided support and monitored their progress across their 50 hours of field work. The 4th year Bachelor of Education Students were tasked with assisting me to create another sustainability education project.
column17: I work collaboratively with colleagues to establish productive partnerships and achieve positive outcomes. I understand that when staff members work together, they form important professional relationships and draw support from each other to improve project outcomes. I am committed to life-long personal and professional development. I conduct critical reflections based on the effectiveness of any projects I work on. I request feedback from community stakeholders and engage with feedback loops to determine areas of improvement to further enhance the outcomes of my projects. Through reflective and professional discussion, I am able to work with a variety of different interest groups to determine ways to meet competing needs of schools, students, teachers, and the Townsville community.

column16: · Safety – I am very passionate about and pride myself in championing a mentally healthy and safe workplace, and supporting my colleagues whenever and wherever I can. I check in with many of my colleagues on a regular basis, especially ones who I know need a bit more support, for whatever reason and make sure they know they have a friendly and supportive ear. I consider mental safety and wellbeing to be just as important as physical. · Excellence – Role-Based Access – continual improvement & working with the whole of IT to try and implement the new, operational BAU across the Section. · Respect – I always value my colleagues’ opinions and interact positively. While I do have excellent communication skills; however, I do need to work more on my active listening skills. · Value – I am very goal orientated and thus adept at identifying required action items to complete tasks I am assigned. For example, despite being constantly faced with numerous hurdles and lack of team members / support from managers with RBAC, I have successfully driven the completion of the initial rollout. Also, my recent work to operationalise RBAC has meant I have made many decisions around prioritising work, building new functionality, and developing processes required for successful implementation. I have focused on ensuring we have at least a minimum viable product which is functional, with the understanding that it will be developed iteratively over time and not wanting to overengineer solutions from the outset. Enjoyment – I often send shout outs to Jared, singing the praises of people I’ve worked with and celebrating what they have achieved. I also try to make people smile and laugh, and help my colleagues out as often as possible.
column17: · Documenting and presenting information in a clear and concise way.· Carefully analyse all potential options to determine best ways of doing something and/or achieving a goal.· Organised, driven, and meticulous. I take full ownership of any tasks I'm assigned and have successfully acted in many different functional Roles across IT Services.· Developed quite a bit of technical knowledge while working on the Role-Based Access project and have become an SME in access provisioning.· I am true to myself and that authenticity, I believe, has enabled me to build many great working relationships with my peers both in IT Services and across the business.
column18: · What do you want to do professionally achieve in the next 5 years?Work for an environmental government agency in a Project Management and/or Business Analysis capacity, preferably in a Role where I can utilise my background in Marine Biology. Consider opportunities in leadership Roles. · Career movement or skill development?Both – I’m keen to develop myself in any way I can. I never want to stop learning new skills, trying new things, and developing my career as a whole. · Flexible work arrangements, retirement?Flexible work arrangements in the sense of being able to work from home. · What does excite you about coming to work?The amazing people, the potential to successfully achieve goals I’ve set and tasks I need to complete, opportunities to develop myself/career and learn new things and skills. · What would excite you about coming to work?Working somewhere where everyone actually takes responsibility for and does their job – working together to improve things for ourselves and the organisation as a whole. Being able to focus on things that matter as a cohesive unit and not spend so much time discussing how we should or shouldn’t do things and just make decisions and act on them – start small and develop iteratively.

column20: 1. 70.20.10 model 70 – Experiential learning:· Put my hand up for and take advantage of opportunities whenever they arise – whether that is secondments and/or projects and tasks that may be outside of my normal comfort zone to challenge myself and try new things. · When trying new workshops and techniques, self-evaluate what worked well and what didn’t really work and continually update and improve my BA toolkit.· I need to work on building my self-confidence, something which I believe will improve by increasing my skills and experience.· I need to reflect on my work more often, being specifically mindful of getting bogged down in detail and overanalysing situations and tasks. In doing so, I can lose sight of the bigger picture.  20 – Social learning: · Continue to coach and mentor ITS staff in Role-Based Access related processes. · Continue to ask for feedback on both work I produce and how I work, using it to grow and develop both in my career and on personal/professional development levels. · Continue to be curious and never stop asking questions to better understand new and existing things, as well as determine where my knowledge gaps are and use my peers’ SME knowledge to help me to understand everything related to current and future projects best I can. 10 – Formal learning · Obtain ECBA certification (training complete – exam needed)· Complete Project Management AND Agile PM training and certification· Complete ITIL Foundations training & certification  2. SMART model · Specific – What specifically am I trying to achieve?Build on my current skills as a BA, and upskill in the field of Project Management.  · Measurable – How will I measure success?Certifications obtained in both fields · Attainable – What steps do I need to take to achieve my goal?Enrol in and complete training and exams. · Relevant – Is this relevant for my long-term objectives? Is this the right time?Yes – long term objective = working in a PM/BA-type capacity in the field of Marine Biology, and I need to upskill in both fields of BA & PM as well as get as much experience as possible in both areas to add to my resume.  · Time-bound – What is the timeframe for the goal?Aiming to attain 1 certification within a year, 2 by 2024.

column18: What do you want to professionally achieve in the next 5 years?I love the opportunities to impart my knowledge to others, so In 5 years I would love to be in, or well on my way towards, a position where I can mentor/provide training to others looking to develop themselves in the Software Development field Career movement or skill development?I am happy working in a Software Development position.I would like to further develop my Software Development skills, particularly in ServiceNow, but also in other tools/environments that would help me to develop professionally Flexible work arrangements, retirement.I like the current ability to work around school pickups/drop-offs, and the capability to be flexible for other events/situations when needed What does excite you about coming to work?Interesting challengesWorking with people with a willingness to try new ideas What would excite you about coming to work?Something along the lines of coding challenges. It doesn’t have to be coding, specifically.Some of the things I really enjoyed when I was studying Game Design were the challenges; there were 24 hour and 48 hour game design challenges, in which we had that set amount of time to work as a team to complete the full process of brainstorm > design > build > test > publish, leading to a playable game at the end. column20: My L&D goals are to progress in my Software Development career, building a large skillset to allow undertaking many varied challenges, as well as being able to provide mentorship to future Software Developers. I have found the following course path run by ServiceNow that will help me to head towards that goal:Low/Pro-Code Integration Developer - Now Learning (servicenow.com) This path includes several free courses that I can complete online from my desk (one of which, I have already completed, along with the prerequisites) which provide the introduction to the environments and tools. It also includes 2 paid courses to allow me to gain the full knowledge benefit of the course path, and allow me to undertake a ServiceNow certification to be a Certified Application Developer in ServiceNow. These 2 courses come in 2 variants; on-demand and instructor-led.The on-demand courses are completed online without any direction/assistance from an instructor and cost USD$300 each (total UASD$600):Scripting in ServiceNow Fundamentals On Demand - Now LearningApplication Development Fundamentals On Demand - Now Learning (servicenow.com) The instructor-led courses are completed online in a virtual class with an instructor and would provide a much greater benefit due to the nature of learning as a group. The cost of these are USD$2400 each (total UASD$4800):Scripting in ServiceNow Fundamentals - Now LearningApplication Development Fundamentals - Now Learning (servicenow.com) Another course that would be of great benefit to any member of IT (not just me) is the ITIL v4 Foundations course (AUD$2035):ITIL® 4 Foundation | DDLS - Leading Corporate IT Training and Certification Provider

column16: Transitioned from Senior Traffic & Infrastructure Planning Engineer role to Coordinator Strategic Infrastructure Planning (SIP) Role. Realigned the SIP team to be an effective team within EAIP having previously been part of the Planning & Development Division.
column17: 35 years experience in infrastructure planning, design and construction for public and private development
column18: At the pinnacle of my career (approximately 12 years ago) I was the the COO for New Zealand Operation for a international consulting firm that delivered strategic planning advice to Council's and NZ Government in the transportation sector. I moved back to Australia for family reasons,  and found my way to Townsville City Council. My previous role as Senior Traffic & Infrastructure Planning Engineer was a perfect fit to my skill set and I continue to perform the duties of that role as well as my current role as Coordinator Strategic Infrastructure Planning. I believe I perform both roles with a high level of competence in line with SERVE values. I think one my achievements in performing my roles within council is significantly improving the systems and processes we use to provide "fit-for-purpose' transport networks to meet the needs for Townsville both now and into the future. eg. development of the Townsville Aimsun Integrated Model which is recalibrated annually and re-writing the transport elements of the City Plan and Development Manual are my accomplishments. I do however believe I have more to offer potentially as Team Manager Asset Infrastructure Planning, position title taken from the new proposed EAIP Structure currently under review.  I am also thinking towards retirement and work security as I get older, I am 56. So I am somewhat concerned about the implications if I move onto a management contract if I pursue the Team Manager Asset Infrastructure Planning position.
column19: Remain in current role, Flexible Working Arrangement, Seeking promotion

column16: - coordinated and delivered environmental and landscape restorative projects across the city for the benefit of the community and local environment- delivered complex projects with multiple layers including; design, legislation, safety and logistics.- built the capacity of multiple local businesses and staff to deliver restorative works, and respond to environmental incidents.- provided cost savings, and risk reductions to council and community through restorative works along natural areas such as coastlines and riverbanks, and implemented circular economy initiatives such as 'Weeds to Healthy Soils' (collaborating with multiple TCC departments).- collaborated across departments, with state and federal government to strategically support water quality for GBR outcomes, Biodiversity Offsets, etc.

column18: Goal:Within the next 5 years, my vision is that I will be: - leading and delivering environmental and sustainability projects, programs, and core services - with a focus on landscape and catchment restoration. - build, be responsible for and coordinate a resourced team for delivering the below outcomes for Townsville's environment and community. - leading and amplifying landscape restorative programs and initiatives - more low-cost, high-impact restorative projects across: riverbanks, savannas, coastlines, gullies and catchments - continuing the delivery and lead restorative works within the Ross Dam catchment (at a larger scale), synergising with a whole of catchment strategy for stacked offsets (carbon, biodiversity, reef), while delivering water quality outcomes into the drinking water catchment (providing a management and cost saving) - My vision is to be supporting the delivering of this project - collaborating with Townsville Water, Planning, to deliver in a case-study worthy framework for integrated, actual and meaningful long-term outcomes in an offset / catchment restoration context. - My vision within the next 5 years is to be internally resourced with a team for delivering the above mentioned - with support for administration, technical, supervisory and delivery assistance (currently a barrier for delivering at a greater scale, and currently results in lost opportunities). - My vision within the next 5 years is to lead and deliver a program for TCC (as trustees) to collaborate with leasees (graziers) of land, to deliver restorative landscape function outcomes, and in turn generating better outputs for leasees (graziers). My vision is that this program will generate greater water quality and biodiversity outcomes, presents an opportunity for offsets (to assist in funding), AND will also increase the value of this land.   Reality:  Options: Will:

column16: I have been on secondment in this role since Feb 2022. In November 2022 I was successful at gaining a permanent Business Support Officer role.To begin with I was based at the ACAC enjoying providing administration support to the staff and serving the public.In July 2022 I started working with the BSU Team at Walker Street (we have since moved to Bamford Lane), my main focus being on the RS Complaints inbox.While Laurelle was away, I assisted with providing admin support for Food licences, Skin penetration licences & ERA approvals.On a separate occasion while Laurelle was away, I provided admin support for the EHS Councillor Complaints, maintaining the spreadsheet and email inbox.Currently my focus is on parking correspondence and the BSU to Action folder (helping the ACAC BSU staff)

column20: GOAL - Become cross skilled, confident & proficient in the extensive range of duties, roles and functions that our BSU Team performs and maintains, including the financial responsibilities.  SPECIFIC - In depth understanding of the finer details that are required and involved to perform the extensive range of duties, roles and functions that our BSU Team performs and maintains. MEASURABLE - One way I will measure my success is by feedback provided by management, my peers and other departments. Another form of measurement will be the ability to perform duties in a more proficient / timely manner. ATTAINABLE - The main steps I can think of to achieve my goal will be -Time - time to learn while doing the job at hand & from my peers, time to become efficient, time performing the duties, tasks etcPatience - With myself, it is not expected that I learn everything at once and will become an expert overnight.Focus - be open to learning from peers around you yet stay focused on the job at hand. Do not become distracted or sidetracked by outside interruptions. Coaching - from my team mates and others that have knowledge of the task / duty that I'm learning RELEVANCEI believe my goal is relevant now that I'm permanent in the BSU Officer position and the right time for me to now expand my knowledge and become a more productive, knowledgeable member of the team. TIME BOUNDIn the next 6 months I would like to evidence within myself and my work that my skills have become more varied and knowledge more extensive

column17: Agile Highly networked throughout Townsville Impartial in most situationsPatient
column18: Truthfully, I do not have a true definitive direction that I wish to follow at this stage (pending changes within the next 2+ years), however in an ideal world I do have preferences based on the resources, limitations and time that I currently have.  1-2 Year Goal: The number one goal regardless of what I have planned is to get wifey back into operating her business full time or part time (before Willow starts school). While this might not be my own personal development plan, this will be our prime focus for me and my family within the next two years (hopefully sooner). The reason this is relevant is because this ties into our long-term plans (potentially within the next 5 years), and all activities in between.  From a personal perspective, I'd be more than happy to continue growing and learning within Stakeholder Engagement. I would like to reach a level where I feel confident in every situation and have a good understand how to action/resolve each problem - I try to work on this every day. I think this can easily be achieved simply by surrounding myself in different projects and with repetition, potentially with further studies or IAP2 training. I would also like to reach a point where I feel confident to review my current Position Description (PD) to reflect my contributions within Stakeholder Engagement so that I'm not classified as a 'Customer Service Rep'. (ie. going up levels).  I would like to get better at time management, project management, problem solving, marketing, and networking within the town (internally & externally).  Another part of me would like to get into a creative space again, however I do not know what that truly looks like. Since starting my small local business, I have found a spark for 'creating' again - I've been enjoying the designing, photography & videography aspects of the business and could easily see myself doing this as a career. Stakeholder Engagement has also contributed to this each time I have gone out to get project update photos for Have Your Say - it might not seem like a creative activity, however it is something I take pride in and enjoy. Unfortunately this type of career change would be harder to achieve as this would require some form of study / learning program and time is restrict enough as it is, however I will not rule this out as an option.  In order for this to become realistic, wifey & I would need to both be working comfortably and ideally Willow would need to be at school as daycare is not an option. (Night school or off-campus study would also work).  3-4 Year Plan: Both parties (Kim & I) working full time with Willow at school, making study / workshops / personal development freely available whilst two incomes are steadily flowing. If still within Council, 'climb the ladder'.  Potentially look at secondments and work in other departments for further exposure, development and understanding just as I have done since start at Council. I enjoy mixing it up.  5+ Year Plan: Personally I find it hard to think about what 5 Years time will look like, however eventfully I would like to go into full-time business, whether that be clothing, printing services, collectables, or something else creative I would ultimately like to call it 'my own'. All of these things are currently hobbies that I do on a daily basis, however hopefully one day, one of these hobbies will flourish into something  bigger. I can not hide the fact that I love the 'hustle' and do entrepreneurial things however I have come to terms that there is a lot of risk involved with doing these activities full-time / steadily, which is why Council will remain in the equation for as long as possible / long as it needs to be.  If I find that these 'dreams' are not achievable or realistic by this time in life, I would be content with remaining in Council (government) due to the steadiness and consistency. However by this point I would like to have achieved the following: - Some form of study to compliment my career and/or personal choices. - Exposure to management within a role - Confident in high level problem solving - Be higher up than a level 3 haha.   (Soz Hannay, my IDP might be the messiest one in Council but hopefully I've given you enough to work on something).

column17: For the most part I am a practical person, I try to bring that into the projects the team completes when providing direction.  That includes ensuring that the works we undertake takes into account future planning.  Just because a task is cheaper now, will that make it cheaper in the future.  This includes planning - trying to make a shift for the team to undertake forward plannning.
column18: The role in currently is my growth step.  I found my previous role was becoming boring..My plan for the next few years is to get the team working under practical plans/schedules that have long term outcomes (eg weed control).This will require filling the team positions with the right people and directing them to create practical programs and ensuring there is mechanism (Darrens crew or funding) to get the works done.I need to learn more about Biosecurity (particularly the Act and how that dictates delivery on ground) as well as general coastal management.I dont intend to be a specialist in these fields, but to have more confidence to guide decision making in these areas.I also need to gain more skills in the EBA and keep growing my leadership skills. It is sometimes difficult having stepped up from within the team to TL, especially when working with friends.  It something i am continuing to work on.I would also like to gain skills in public speaking - its something i am not good at, but have found i need to build skills in.

column20: I would like to gain more knowledge in Biosecurity Act and how it dictates Biosecurity delivery and obligations.I need to spend more time digesting the Act, but could also talk to other local councils on the programs they have developed (eg 1080 baiting, Control and Prvention and Surveilance strategies).I need to learn more about general coastal management and how the local tidal system impacts our coastlines.  Will undertake more inspections with Alma and Adam King to discuss coastal works and future planning.I would also like the opportunity to attend seminars to help grow my knowledge in these areas, as well as bushfire management.  Attending these events is also a great way to meet other council groups working in these areas and learn from them aswell.Our team provides advice on Bushfire Plans for DA's - i would like to attend a formal course in this to further inform the recommendations the team provides but also assist the DA team - as they only have 1 person in the team with this skill set .I would also like to undertake additional training in the EBA (if there is  internal training) or allocate time to digest this, and further leadership training.

column16: Created detailed procedure documents for the Digital Team’s BAU tasks to ensure new and existing team members can undertake all tasks, and to strengthen business continuity. Created templates to guide staff when they request work, reports or analytics thereby creating efficiencies by ensuring all required information is included in the request. Introduced monthly one-on-one meetings and weekly Work in Progress meetings for my team to improve project management, employee training and development, health & safety reporting, and creating an opportunity to address any issues, share feedback and ideas. Ensured all work undertaken by the Digital Team is tracked and recorded in ServiceNow to ensure records management compliance and accurate tracking of the team’s workload and workflow. Implemented and improved tools that measure our digital environment’s performance and adherence to regulatory, policy, accessibility and best practice guidelines. Decommissioned old and poorly functioning websites including:· Northern Stories· TaskforceNQ· Townsville2020· Water Security Taskforce· Water Smart Portal Built or made improvements to:· TaskforceNQ website· Mayor’s Christmas Appeal website· Northern Fringe Festival website· North Australian Festival of Arts website· Arts Network Townsville website· Townsville Dashboards website· What’s On Townsville website redesign· TCC website homepage redesign· TCC intranet homepage redesign· Internal Community Engagement Portal· Current Projects section redesign with interactive map· Laboratory Services portal renewal· Strand Ephemera portal renewal· Sustainability Tours portal renewal Highlights:· Temporarily delivered the live streaming of Council meetings with just one week notice.· Was part of the Disaster Comms team for the 2019 Flood event· Took over the build and management of Council’s $10 million Water Smart Package program website just 3 weeks before launch in order to make the site operational. Continued to update, bug fix and generate reports for the program for 12 weeks as the Project Manager had no plan in place, no experience in this field, no website build specification documentation and continually changed their reporting requirements.· Converted more than 500 weblinks to ensure key documents on the intranet continued to work when IT rolled out the CIAnywhere changeover with less than 2 weeks’ notice.· Took over responsibility for delivering Internal Communications.· The number of tasks completed annually by the Digital Team since I began has increased by 600% - growing from 1,031 tasks in 2017 to almost 6,000 tasks in 2021.

column16: Keeping on track of work whilst I was the only filled position out of a team of three and only had a few months of training. Stepping up to train the new staff that filled the other positions in the Collection team, including the senior collection officer which is a senior position to mine. Participating in organising the pack up of Thuringowa Library, both physically and in planning. As well as organising the move of the collections to other branches. This included major weeding in the weeks leading up to the close, reshuffling of collections to accommodate excess items moving to the other branches, creating of procedures for staff, and communicating with a range of different teams across the library to share information. I have worked really well in a new team to undergo a huge project in a short time and am continuing to work to strengthen how efficiently that team works together. I have been elected as a HSR, have completed the HSR training and have worked to improve safety in the library space. I have done this by attending the library Health and Safety committee meetings, participating in regular housekeeping inspections, and raising work orders to get hazards fixed. Giving a presentation to my colleagues on my experience at QPLA Conference that I attend in Oct 2022. This presentation was something that I was anxious about but was able to present well.
column17: The strengths that I bring to my role and team include:I have a good attention to detail, which helps me to find errors in records, identify hazards in the workplace, helping to create detailed plans.I am an active listener and can clearly communicate my ideas. Being able to ask questions when I need more clarification or need help. I can provide constructive feedback as well as positively receive feedback, reflect on it and make changes to either my work, ideas or plans. I am able to brainstorm, and problem solve which are major aspects of my role and how my team works together. I am passionate about learning and am a curious person. This helps me to learn new processes, to question the 'why' behind things and to see if there is a different or more efficient way of doing something.

column16: In my current role, I am proud to have contributed the following:  IPWEAQ:  Last year, the TCC traffic management team worked with other regional councils to develop the IPWEAQ Traffic Management Toolkit. The toolkit was designed to support the planning and design of safe, cost effective and efficient temporary traffic management solutions. Our work on this project earned TCC recognition and acknowledgement from IPWEAQ for our contribution.  Link Below:  https://ipweaq.intersearch.com.au/ipweaqjspui/bitstream/1/7473/1/1.%20TTM%20Toollkit%20TMP%20reference%20document_Final.pdf   Event Management - I have been working closely with QPS, and the TCC events team to develop hostile vehicle mitigation plans for major events, including Townsville Eats, ANZAC Day, Freedom of Entry ect.  Hostile vehicle mitigation involves the strategic placement of concrete barriers, miframs, or parked vehicles to mitigate the risk of errant vehicles driving through crowded events.    Generic TGSs: I have been updating our suite of generic TGSs to the new AUSROADs standard. The utility of having generic TGSs is that we can use them in for works in situations that don't particularly require complex traffic management solutions. Using generics for simple jobs means instead of being weighed down drawing every plan for every job, we can better utilize our time to perform our other duties such as site inspections, audits, ect.
column17: I believe my strength that I bring to the team is:  >My extensive experience as a traffic management implementer/team leader over a ten-year long career. > My diligence in staying up to date with the new AUSROADs standards for temp. traffic management, ensuring TCC remains compliant with legislative requirements.>My background in health and safety. In my previous job I was ALTUS's safety rep for the Townsville region, in that time I contributed to the development of their new SWMS alongside other HSR committee members.  > My enthusiasm to develop innovations to improve productivity and safety.  Most recently, I had the idea to put a QR code on our stop/slow TGSs that would direct traffic controllers to an online- queue length calculator.  A dynamic solution to address the requirements of a site-specific queue length.
column18: What do you want to professionally achieve in the next 5 years? >Expand my knowledge and utility by undergoing more training. >Go on the on-call B roster. >I would like to commute more with other industry professionals. IPWEAQ and TMAA hold regular conferences about temp. traffic management.> I would like to expand upon our library of generic TGSs to further streamline our workflow.  >Update our library of TGSs reoccurring works (POSE, electrical) to the new standards. >Potentially studying Traffic Engineering?  · Flexible work arrangements, retirement:  >I think that council should implement a hybrid system where those with the capacity to do so can work from home for 1-2 days a fortnight.This will work to mitigate the rising costs of commuting to work and improve worker morale.  · What does excite you about coming to work? > I enjoy coming up with solutions to complicated traffic control requirements/problems.

column18: In the coming years, I am most interested in completing projects that make a positive difference to the city and increasing my level of responsibility within the organisation. I will be leading the Flood and Coastal hazard, and Housing Strategy studies in the coming year. I will also be assisting with the integration of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander interests in the planning scheme, and the development of an Environmental Offsets strategy. I hope to lead and assist other similar projects over the coming years. In working on these projects, I hope to continue to grow my professional skills and take on greater responsibility. In addition, I am hoping to enhance my professional development in other ways. I have been able to attend some workshops and industry breakfasts this year, which has been beneficial for my knowledge acquisition. In the coming year, I would like to be able to attend a conference and/or have more opportunities to attend workshops. Moving forward, while my day-to-day preference is to work from the office, I wish to be able to work from home where suitable. The Covid-19 pandemic has enhanced the ability for many people to be able to work remotely, and I think this still has a place post-pandemic. Previously, people who had some signs of illness but felt well enough to work would often attend work, but this would expose other people to their illness. I see these situations as the perfect example of when working from home is the best outcome for all. Having a sense that I am contributing to positive change to our city excites me about coming to work. So too, is the knowledge that I work with many great and interesting people, who are all motivated to influence positive change. I would be further excited about coming to work knowing that I am working on profound and interesting projects. Moving forward, I have interest in being involved in projects that work in the urban landscape, especially to do with assisting infill development, transport planning and placemaking. As an inner-city dweller, this has particular importance to me, as a I wish to assist in improving the development pattern of our city.

column16: I fixed long entrenched errors with the serials, using an understanding developed through a combination of learning from others, and my own experimentation and problem solving. I identified that previous fixes for the errors did not address the root of the problem and that we needed a solution for the main cause of all the errors. As the serials were greatly neglected when I came into this role, and with very little serials knowledge or experience in the new team, I am proud of what I learned and how hard I worked to fix the errors and get it functioning properly. I consistently contributed to the Riverway collections working group and put in a lot of hard work with the Thuringowa closure, often working autonomously to collect data, make decisions, and weed a huge amount of items.  I developed and delivered several training sessions for new staff regarding the collection.  I trained several staff members and work experience students in areas such as courier, bulk loan selections and delivery, serials, circulation tasks, and shelving.  I presented to the GM at a meeting.  I provided a consistently high level of customer service, both on the floor and in my role when talking to bulk loan customers and purchasing item requests.  I helped organise the Share the Dignity donations  I figured out how to activate an RFID tag without having to catalogue an item for use on the board games for after-hours activities. Discovered that RFID tags do not work on iPads. This was done to provide a service for the L&I team.  Worked with the team to create new processes and written procedures such as handling the Iron Mountain items, a spreadsheet for re-ordering items while on the floor, how to fix common issues with serials.  Led the weeding and transfer of collections such as home service stack, large print and YA manga. Worked to make sure bulk loan selections were always done on time.  Catalogued several books myself, which involved downloading or creating a record from scratch, adding holdings, choosing a Dewey number, creating a spine label, and sending it to Michelle to process. Sparked lots of great conversations in the team about where items belong in our collection and why.  Created and deployed several Facebook and Instagram posts to promote the collection. Generated Facebook stats each month for the business development planning officers.  Uploaded and maintained the digital screens in each of the branches.  Worked to maintain the catalogue by deleting lost items, refreshing popular items, organising series, uploading and editing MARC records, and actioning high demand item reports.
column17: I consistently speak up, contribute and give feedback in meetings or when working in a team. I am also good at listening to others, considering other points of view and taking on feedback. I am good at written communication and will always lend a hand to proofread for a colleague or help write a procedure, a powerpoint, toolbox, etc.  I am good at decision making and considering the long-term outcomes of decisions.  I am honest and diligent which makes me reliable and trustworthy when working in a team.  I make an effort to communicate what I am doing or what I’m working on so that my team is on the same page.  I am good at problem solving and seeing a task or problem through to completion.
column18: Goal: to become skilled at BAU tasks and able to spend more time on projects as a team.  Reality: majority of time is currently spent working individually on BAU tasksor searching for something to do with no direction. Obstacles: CS shifts, having to work across branches, difficulty finding an efficient way to allocate BAU tasks, difficulty communicating or a lack of ‘checking in’ with team, and the learning curve that the team is still undergoing.Options: Having a schedule for when team members will be at Aitkenvale, finding a tool to fairly allocate tasks that works for everyone, a consistent daily check in with the team, and taking the time to teach one another and share the tasks so that everyone has the same knowledge and can practice it.  Way forward: team building workshops, getting to know how each other work and communicate, asking other team members for help and offering my help to them to facilitate team work.  The above goal is for the next 1-2 years, after that I would like to focus on promoting the collection, in particular reader’s advisory where we can help children, teens and adults find content that is relevant to them.

column16: I have ensured a safe and effective work site for employees and public members, bringing to attention any discrepancies and safety issues to my supervisor and team members.  I have endeavoured to keep up to date with any changes to safety procedures and legislation to the best of my ability and believe I have performed my tasks safely and effectively. I believe that while I am still the least experienced within the traffic control team, I have gained enough skills and knowledge to conduct my work effectively and without issue.  I have commonly been tasked with handling jobs and sites solo and have performed these tasks to an adequate level.  I have also performed well during emergency scenarios.
column17: I believe I bring an analytical approach to tasks and issues that may arise, developed during my studies at university.  I tend to think through the plans and safety meetings and look at things in a different perspective than my fellow co-workers, potentially bringing up points of interest they have not considered.  This is supported by my relative lack of experience within the traffic control industry (three years) so I am unaware of multiple topics considered common sense.  This causes me to ask questions that may lead to the team and I to come up with new solutions. I believe I have an ability to remain relatively calm and analyse emergency scenarios.  In situations of high stress, I endeavour to remain calm and think through the situation.  While this may cause me to be slow to react at first, I believe this helps me to be more effective once I have determined the tasks that needed to be done and the order they are to be completed. Finally, I believe my years of experience within the fast-food industry have provided me with extensive customer service and conflict resolution experience.  I believe I have a calming presence and am able to handle myself in communicating with members of the public, including ones in an agitated state.  I am also able to quickly determine if a situation needs to be elevated and work to quickly resolve situations to ensure a happy resolution for all involved.
column18: Over the next five years, I hope to be promoted or moved to a position that allows me to use my Bachelor of Science qualification.  I have already completed a three-month secondment with the Townsville Water Laboratory located on Angus Smith Drive and hope to move to a more permanent position as a Laboratory Assistant. Afterwards, I hope to gain sufficient experience and skills to be promoted to Lab Tech or even Scientist to perform more in-depth testing.  Being able to use the knowledge and skills I learned and developed during my time at JCU would make me more excited to come to work and would be a more suitable fit for me within the Townsville City Council. For knowledge or skills development, I would like to eventually move towards working on Master's qualification or even a PhD, but that is much further into the future.

column16: Having started in this team as a trainee in 2020, I was a set of fresh eyes to the team. When learning tasks like the inbox procedures and water board, the procedures I was learning off were out of date and were not allowing me to benefit/learn from them. I updated all procedures and created procedures for some tasks that were not in the O-Drive. These are now used to teach new members in our team. They were all designed around the way I learn. Everyone learns differently, so I have encouraged the team to edit these themselves to suit their own personal learning ways. Coming into my third year in the team, I am across every single task. This means that when we have a staff shortage, I would be able to pick up anyone's tasks. I also can multi-task and can complete multiple staff members' roles as well as my own.  I believe I have done incredibly well in my time here and I am proud of my efforts and proud that I can teach new people off my own work.

column16: Achieving a focus on our SERVE values. Some examples of the changes implemented are highlighted below.  Implemented $4.78M contracting program in a period of 5 months from start to implementation. This has reduced:- grass mowing requests by 11%- herbicide requests of TCC assets by 9%- completion of slashing schedules from 83% to 96%Current tendering for Open Space Contract has been recognised as best practice by councillors and contractors for the way in which it has been communicated.  Implementation of operational plan:Current overall schedule completion within parks at 95%.  Implementation of change in median and roadside maintenance procedures to eliminate stone throws to passing traffic. 0 incidents reported since June this year.
column17: Collaboration - I work well across the council teams as well as up and down from my current position. I have been integral to the delivery of the Bushland Beach Naturalisation project with the Environmental Services and Water teams. I have also worked well with the events teams for NAFA and community development to implement projects such as the Great Australian Bird Count, friends of botanics and cemetery improvements.  People Management - current vacancies with the Parks team are at an all time low. This has been achieved through a targeted recruitment regime with a focus on team fit. This has allowed retention to be increased reducing the workload in recruitment.The Parks team has been restructured with minimal concerns raised and an increase in the delivery of scheduled works.  An Operation Focus - A number of changes in delivery of scheduled works has occurred to allow the works to be delivered more efficiently. This has included placing the slashers teams with the ground crews to allow team leaders to have all of the required tools and eliminate a culture of "it's not my job".
